items.title: 2 federal agents involved in shooting of Alex Pretti in Minneapolis have been placed on leave
items.summary_auto: Two federal agents who were involved in ​Saturday's fatal shooting of a U.S. citizen in Minneapolis have been placed on administrative leave, according to a U.S. Customs and Border Protection spokesperson.

items.title: Ontario government to fast-track new transmission line to Ring of Fire region
items.summary_auto: Ontario has designated the Greenstone Transmission Line as a priority project as the province proceeds with plans to develop the lucrative Ring of Fire region. The line will run from Nipigon Bay to near Aroland First Nation and what the province calls the “gateway to the Ring of Fire.”

items.title: Venezuela 'untenable situation' that had to be addressed, Rubio says about Maduro capture
items.summary_auto: Secretary of State Marco Rubio told the U.S. Senate on Wednesday that Venezuela's new leaders were moving toward closer ties with Washington without the immediate need for further U.S. military action, as he publicly faced questions from many of his former colleagues for the first time.

items.title: More criminals are using AI for ransomware attacks, cybersecurity centre warns
items.summary_auto: The federal cybersecurity centre warns in a new report that criminals who hold data for ransom are using artificial intelligence tools that make it easier to target their victims.

items.title: Ontario PCs bar reporters from policy convention
items.summary_auto: Ontario’s Progressive Conservatives will not allow reporters to attend their annual gathering in Toronto this weekend, a move critics say breaks from democratic norms.

items.title: Netherlands must cut CO2 to protect Caribbean island of Bonaire, court rules
items.summary_auto: A court has ordered the Dutch government to draw up a plan to protect residents on the tiny Caribbean island of Bonaire from the devastating effects of climate change — a sweeping victory for the islanders.

items.title: Shane's Heated Rivalry Team Canada fleece is finally being released
items.summary_auto: Almost as soon as Crave's breakout hockey romance Heated Rivalry hit the screens, so did the frenzy over Shane Hollander's Team Canada zip-up fleece.

items.title: IN PHOTOS | Meet Church of England's 1st female leader
items.summary_auto: Sarah Mullally was officially confirmed on Wednesday as the first woman to lead the Church of England as Archbishop of Canterbury at a traditional ceremony at St Paul's Cathedral in London.

items.title: Canada in talks with Meta on return of news to Facebook as CUSMA review nears
items.summary_auto: The federal government says its willingness to speak with Meta about the possibility of seeing online news return to Facebook is part of an ongoing conversation Canada is having with the digital giant as the review of CUSMA nears.

items.title: Minnesota, other states reject Trump administration requests for private voter information
items.summary_auto: The fatal shootings of two Minnesota residents by federal government agents have put the focus on the immigration blitz on the streets of Minneapolis, but on Monday a judge raised a skeptical eye toward the Trump administration's overall pressure campaign on the state.

items.title: Former French senator found guilty of drugging lawmaker with intent to assault her
items.summary_auto: A former French senator was found guilty by a Paris court late on Tuesday of having spiked a lawmaker's drink with ecstasy with the intention of sexually assaulting her.

items.title: Bank of Canada holds interest rate at 2.25%, with CUSMA review an 'important risk'
items.summary_auto: The Bank of Canada is holding its key interest rate at 2.25 per cent for a second consecutive meeting, a move that was widely expected by analysts.

items.title: Russia denies think-tank assessment that 1.2 million of its troops have been killed or injured in Ukraine war
items.summary_auto: The Kremlin is denying a report that Russia suffered the largest number of casualties recorded for any major power in any conflict since the Second World War.

items.title: 'We were supposed to grow old together': Fiancée mourns man found day after Ottawa crash
items.summary_auto: The fiancée of a man who was found dead in the snow after a crash last week in Ottawa is remembering him as a devoted father who worked long hours and came so near to seeing his family again.

items.title: Amazon lays off 16,000 corporate workers in latest round of job losses
items.summary_auto: Amazon is slashing about 16,000 corporate jobs in the second round of mass layoffs for the e-commerce company in three months.

items.title: Alberta greenlights $900M borrowing authority for provincial oil and gas agency
items.summary_auto: Alberta has authorized the province’s commercial oil and gas agency to borrow nearly $1 billion for market investments, a move which could attract a private proponent to invest in a pipeline to the B.C. coast, according to one expert.

items.title: B.C. government struck compromise with assisted dying policy, court hears
items.summary_auto: The B.C. government's policy on medical assistance in dying involved striking a compromise between faith-based health-care providers who didn't want to allow the procedure in their buildings and complying with Canada's assisted dying laws, B.C. Supreme Court heard this week.

items.title: Woman who threw scalding water on Longueuil, Que., child gets 27-month sentence
items.summary_auto: A 47-year-old woman who threw scalding water on a young child in Longueuil, Que. and pleaded guilty to aggravated assault back in September was sentenced to 27 months in prison on Wednesday.

items.title: Wife of former South Korean president sentenced to 20 months for bribery
items.summary_auto: A South Korean court sentenced former first lady Kim Keon Hee on Wednesday to one year and eight months in jail after finding her guilty of accepting Chanel bags and a diamond pendant from Unification Church officials in return for political favours.

items.title: Alberta’s population could surpass British Columbia’s as early as 2038: StatsCan
items.summary_auto: Alberta could overtake British Columbia as Canada's third most populated province in just over a decade, according to new projections released by Statistics Canada.

items.title: NDP criticizes government hiring of former Sask. Party executive director
items.summary_auto: The Saskatchewan NDP is criticizing the hiring of Patrick Bundrock, the Saskatchewan Party's former executive director, for a new $198,000 a year job with the province's executive council.

items.title: Magnitude 3.7 earthquake rattles southern and central Ontario
items.summary_auto: Thousands of southern and central Ontario residents are reporting that they were shaken by an earthquake late Tuesday night, according to Natural Resources Canada.

items.title: Federal report examines gaps in RCMP response to N.S. mass shooting
items.summary_auto: A workplace incident report investigated the 2020 mass shooting in Nova Scotia which left RCMP Const. Heidi Stevenson and 21 others dead.

items.title: Police investigating students at a Labrador high school alleged to have used AI to create intimate image
items.summary_auto: The Department of Education and Early Childhood Development has confirmed a police investigation into students alleged to have used generative AI to create and share intimate images.

items.title: Millions of Canadian homes have high levels of cancer-causing radon. Is yours one of them?
Why do 3 major diseases disproportionately impact Black Canadians? New genome project aims to find out
items.summary_auto: Researchers in Ontario, Quebec and Nova Scotia are launching a project to map more than 10,000 genomes from Black Canadians with Type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure and an aggressive form of breast cancer. Project leaders hope their findings eventually help target treatment and preventive care and contribute to better health outcomes for racialized patients.

items.title: These Ontario snowbirds are ditching the U.S. and wintering in Mexico
items.summary_auto: Some Ontario residents who typically spend their winters in the U.S. say they’ve recently opted to buy property in Mexico instead. The shift comes as some snowbirds grow uneasy about the political climate under U.S. President Donald Trump.

items.title: This Albertan signed up to fight in Ukraine. He was nearly killed by friendly fire
items.summary_auto: David Rauser spoke to CBC News from western Ukraine after being accidentally shot in the head by a member of his team in Donetsk.

items.title: 'I know I didn't redeem those': Windsor, Ont. man wonders about missing Petro-Points
items.summary_auto: Harvey Lemire of Windsor says $140 worth of his Petro-Points were redeemed at locations he doesn't recognize. He's advising people to check the point balances of any loyalty cards they use — something also advised by the Better Business Bureau of Western Ontario.

items.title: Why solving cold case killings just got much harder for police
items.summary_auto: Police cold-case units face a new challenge in solving decades-old killings. With the world's largest storehouse of genealogy information, Ancestry.com, now banning law enforcement from using its data without obtaining a court order, it is much harder for police to build family trees based on crime-scene DNA and zone in on suspects via their distant relatives.

items.title: Brantford, Ont., police won’t collect assault weapons for federal gun buyback program
items.summary_auto: The Brantford Police Service says it won’t participate in collecting assault weapons from the public as part of the federal government’s gun buyback program.

items.title: How are the NDP leadership hopefuls different? Contrasts emerge as they hit membership deadline
items.summary_auto: In a leadership race where candidates have largely been in agreement, candidates are beginning to show New Democrats what sets them apart.

items.title: I used to focus on my patients' health. Now with ICE, I worry about their safety
items.summary_auto: Justin Ho is a Canadian studying dentistry in Minneapolis. He was taught to treat a patient regardless of who they are. After recent events in the U.S., he's realized that health care cannot be disentangled from the politics of the day.

items.title: Man sprays U.S. lawmaker Ilhan Omar with unknown substance at town hall
items.summary_auto: A man sprayed an unknown substance on Democratic U.S. Rep. Ilhan Omar and was tackled to the ground Tuesday during a town hall in Minneapolis, where tensions over federal immigration enforcement have come to a head after agents fatally shot an intensive care nurse and a mother of three this month.

items.title: 2 federal agents fired shots when Alex Pretti was killed in Minneapolis: U.S. official
items.summary_auto: Two federal officers fired shots during the encounter that killed ICU nurse Alex Pretti in Minneapolis, a U.S. Customs and Border Protection official told Congress in a notice sent Tuesday.
